question.title: caching a serialized immutable object in Jackson
question.body:
Use case

Say I have an HTTP endpoint that constructs an immutable object then sends that immutable object to multiple sinks. Maybe I send it to a couple of message brokers, other HTTP endpoints, a file, whatever.

On each send, let's say Jackson is being used to serialize the immutable object.

Questions

Am I right that I could get a significant performance benefit if Jackson could

  1. recognize (or be told) that the object was immutable and was going to serialized multiple times
  2. cache the result of the first serialization in a byte-sequence of some kind
  3. reuse that byte-sequence on subsequent calls to write...

If there would be a benefit, my second question is: does Jackson or any other popular serialization framework offer this optimization?

Thoughts

If that is a benefit to performance, it would really be nice if the serialization framework offered it. While I could write my own wrapper and memoize the result, I would then lose the type-safety of the calls to the sending functions.

I guess it would still be tricky because each of the sending functions would need to be using the same ObjectMapper (or the same cache, at least).
